title: 106_hr2362
content: The "Fair Care for the Uninsured Act of 1999" is also known as the Act. It introduces a refundable credit for health insurance coverage under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Fair Care for the Uninsured Act of 1999" introduces a refundable credit for health insurance coverage under the Internal Revenue Code. The credit allows individuals to claim an amount paid for qualified health insurance for themselves, their spouse, and dependents against the tax imposed. There are limitations on the credit amount based on monthly coverage limits for each individual. The amount for the taxable year is $1,000 for the taxpayer, $1,000 for the spouse if married and filing jointly, and $500 for dependents eligible for a deduction under section 151(c). The limitation for claiming dependents is 2 individuals per taxpayer, with a special rule for married individuals who do not file jointly. The limitation is divided equally between the individual and their spouse unless agreed otherwise. The term 'coverage month' refers to a month where an individual is covered by qualified health insurance, and the premium is paid by the taxpayer. It does not include months where the individual participates in an employer-subsidized health plan. The term 'coverage month' excludes months where the individual is covered by a benefit chosen under a cafeteria plan or a benefit provided under a flexible spending arrangement. It also excludes months where the individual is entitled to benefits under Medicare or Medicaid. The term 'coverage month' excludes months where the individual receives benefits under specific programs like Medicare, Medicaid, chapter 17 of title 38, or any medical care program under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. It also excludes months where the individual is imprisoned. The term 'coverage month' excludes months where the individual receives benefits under specific programs like Medicare, Medicaid, chapter 17 of title 38, or any medical care program under the Indian Health Care Improvement Act. It also excludes months where the individual is imprisoned under Federal, State, or local authority. The term does not include any month during a taxable year if the individual is present in the United States for fewer than 183 days. Coordination with deduction for health insurance costs of self-employed individuals is required if the taxpayer is eligible to deduct any amount under section 162(l) for the taxable year. Qualified Health Insurance is defined for the purposes of this section. The term 'qualified health insurance' refers to insurance that constitutes medical care as defined in section 213(d), excluding certain benefits. It does not include insurance with substantial benefits classified as excepted benefits. Additionally, medical savings account contributions may be deductible under section 220 for the taxpayer. For the taxable year, payments to a medical savings account are treated as payments for qualified health insurance. No double benefit is allowed for deductions under section 220. Special rules apply for coordination with the medical expense deduction and denial of credit to dependents. No credit is allowed under this section for individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151 by another taxpayer in the same taxable year. Dollar amounts in subsection (b)(2)(A) are adjusted for inflation for taxable years after 2000. Any increase determined under the preceding sentence shall be rounded to the nearest multiple of $50 ($25 in the case of the dollar amount in subsection (b)(2)(A)(iii)). Information Reporting - Subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Code is amended by inserting a new section after section 6050S. "SEC. 6050T. RETURNS RELATING TO PAYMENTS FOR QUALIFIED HEALTH INSURANCE." Any person receiving payments for health insurance coverage must file a return with the IRS, including the names, addresses, and TINs of the individuals covered. For health insurance payments, individuals must provide information on coverage under creditable health insurance, as defined by the Secretary. Creditable health insurance excludes subsidized group plans or other insurance where no credit is allowed under section 35. Statements must be furnished to individuals as required by the IRS. Every person making a return must provide a written statement to individuals showing the person's name, address, phone number, total payments received, and payment information by January 31 of the following year. The return under subsection (a) is required for a specific year. Only the person first receiving an amount on behalf of another person needs to make the return. Assessable penalties include section 6050T relating to payments for qualified health insurance. The amendment to section 6724(d) of the Code includes adding a new subparagraph related to returns for payments for qualified health insurance. Additionally, a clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part III of subchapter A of chapter 61 of the Code. Sec. 6050T relates to payments for qualified health insurance. Conforming amendments are made to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 1999. Additionally, Section 102 discusses the advance payment of credit for purchasers of qualified health insurance. SEC. 102 discusses the advance payment of credit for purchasers of qualified health insurance under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Secretary will make payments to the provider of an eligible individual's qualified health insurance equal to the individual's qualified health insurance credit advance amount. An eligible individual is someone who purchases qualified health insurance and has a qualified health insurance credit eligibility certificate. This certificate certifies the individual's eligibility to receive the credit provided by section 35 for the taxable year. The Secretary will make payments to the provider of an eligible individual's qualified health insurance equal to the individual's qualified health insurance credit advance amount. The term 'qualified health insurance credit advance amount' refers to the Secretary's estimate of the credit allowable under section 35 for the taxable year attributable to the insurance provided by the provider. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out this section. Title II of the legislation focuses on studying safety-net health insurance programs for the medically uninsured. The amendments in this section, including advance payment of health insurance credit, will take effect on January 1, 2000. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on State safety-net health insurance programs to determine the most successful forms in providing health insurance to all willing payers regardless of their health status. Consultation will be done with various stakeholders including the National Governors Association and health insurers. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2000, detailing a study on State safety-net health insurance programs. The report will include recommendations on strengthening existing programs and establishing them in states where they do not exist. State safety-net health insurance programs refer to arrangements under state law providing access to health insurance for medically uninsurable individuals.
